author: cskiraly
content:
I don't think we have arrived to this conclusion.

1, Exposing what you sample, permanently in your topic subscriptions, does increase the attack surface. We can make several steps to decrease this attack surface:
- One is to sample the columns by sending requests (also called peer sampling).
- Second is to diversify where you send these requests (part of our sampling design).
- Finally, one could go for real unlinkability of queries, but that would need anonymized communication, and we didn't go that far.

2. As we reduce the data amount you need in your sample (more columns, or cell-based sampling), the attack surface of individual nodes increases. Without "more complex sampling", it becomes easier to attack individual nodes, or to partition the network.

author: cskiraly
content: 3, Once we will have much more segments (not just 128 or 256 columns, but e.g. 512*512 cells), the subscription model falls apart. You can't easily subscribe to a single cell. Without going into the details, subnet sampling, as is, is much harder to interpret there.

author: cskiraly
content: So currently you can just use subnet sampling, but in the future I foresee we add more complex sampling techniques. Anyway, we can add these gradually.
